content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Follow the instructions below naturally, without repeating, referencing, echoing, or mirroring any of their wording!

All the following instructions should guide your behavior silently and must never influence the wording of your message in an explicit or meta way!

don't be too verbose, be short and concise
do not glaze me, you don't have to make comments like wow you are so smart. 
just be informational and direct. 
Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.```

entries.title: Some Microsoft Office apps are losing access to voice tools soon - here's what to know
entries.snippet:
Starting January 2026, Microsoft will discontinue voice-related features‚Äîsuch as transcription, dictation, and Read Aloud‚Äîin older Office versions that have not been updated to at least version 16.0.18827.20202. This move affects popular applications like Word, Outlook, OneNote, and PowerPoint. Microsoft cites a backend service upgrade as the reason for discontinuing support on older versions, emphasizing improved performance and compatibility with newer systems. Users in Government Cloud environments (GCC, GCC High, and DoD) will receive a two-month extension to implement changes.

Local fallbacks for these voice tools will not be available after the deadline, and those with perpetual licenses may already lack many cloud-based features. In addition to these voice tool changes, Office 2016 and 2019 will reach the end of their extended support by October 14, 2025. Similarly, Office apps on Windows 10 will lose support later in 2025, coinciding with Windows 10's own end-of-life status. These shifts are encouraging broader adoption of Microsoft‚Äôs latest software, with Windows 11 surpassing Windows 10 in installations as of July 2025.

v.title: WeNet 2.0: More Productive End-to-End Speech Recognition Toolkit
Best speech-to-text app of 2025
v.snippet:
This comprehensive 2025 TechRadar guide ranks the top speech-to-text apps and services designed to simplify converting spoken language into written text across mobile, desktop, and cloud platforms. Speech-to-text tools have moved from niche uses to broader applications in business, education, and everyday productivity. As voice recognition accuracy has greatly improved, many platforms now boast around 99% transcription accuracy.

Key offerings include:

- **Speechmatics**, praised for its multilingual, accent-flexible AI-driven transcription tools.
- **Dragon Professional**, ideal for business use with high accuracy and productivity tools.
- **Otter**, optimized for mobile and collaborative note-taking during meetings.
- **Verbit**, tailored for enterprise and education with hybrid AI and human transcription.
- **Braina Pro**, a PC-based voice assistant offering versatile command and dictation support.
- **Microsoft Azure Speech to Text** and **IBM Watson**, both cloud-native enterprise solutions offering real-time and batch transcription with customizable language models.
- **Dragon Anywhere**, a mobile app delivering professional-grade dictation in the cloud.
- **Amazon Transcribe**, optimized for business use with live and batch processing.

Top free options include Google Gboard, Just Press Record, Speechnotes, and built-in features like Windows Speech Recognition. Additional apps like iTranslate, Voice Notes, and SpeechTexter highlight specialized capabilities for translation, note organization, and social media use. The guide concludes with advising selection based on user needs and testing methodology.

v.title: Espresso: A Fast End-to-end Neural Speech Recognition Toolkit
WhisperX: Time-Accurate Speech Transcription of Long-Form Audio
Best dictation software of 2025
v.snippet:
This comprehensive guide from TechRadar reviews the best dictation software for 2025, highlighting tools that convert speech into text efficiently, catering to different needs such as workplace productivity, mobile accessibility, affordability, and multilingual support. Leading the pack is Dragon Professional Individual, praised for its robust accuracy and deep learning capabilities. Microsoft Word's built-in dictation feature stands out for Microsoft 365 users due to its seamless integration and multilingual support. Otter receives recognition for its value, speaker identification, and flexible plans, while Dragon Anywhere excels as a powerful mobile solution.

For Google enthusiasts, Google Docs Voice Typing is a free, user-friendly option, although it lacks offline functionality. Apple users benefit from Apple Dictation, which is free and accurate for short dictations. SpeechTexter appeals to multi-lingual users with support for over 70 languages, though English remains its most accurate. Braina Pro, also a virtual assistant, offers robust customization for power users, while Just Press Record is the best for iCloud users due to its iOS-centric design and iCloud syncing. The article concludes with tips on selecting suitable software based on individual needs and thoroughly outlines the testing methodology used to assess each tool.

v.title: Best text-to-speech software of 2025
v.snippet:
This document from TechRadar (dated September 29, 2025) presents a comprehensive guide to the best text-to-speech (TTS) software of 2025. It emphasizes the growing importance of TTS for accessibility, productivity, and content creation, particularly in media like YouTube and podcasting.

The top picks include:

1. **NaturalReader** ‚Äì Best overall for personal/home use, offering 56 voices across 9 languages and cloud-based access.
2. **Murf** ‚Äì Best for realistic AI voices, ideal for e-learning and presentations, with advanced editing and voice-changing tools.
3. **Amazon Polly** ‚Äì Best for developers, offering easy API integration and broad language support.
4. **Play.ht** ‚Äì Best for podcasting, providing nearly 600 voices in over 60 languages, with options tailored for commercial use.
5. **Voice Dream Reader** ‚Äì Best for Mac and iOS users, offering 186 voices in 30 languages and compatibility with multiple cloud services.

The article also explains the difference between web-based TTS services and desktop software, discusses subscription models, and offers advice for integrating TTS into business workflows. Each software was rigorously tested based on performance, usability, voice quality, and pricing.

entries.title: Windows 11 is gaining a powerful set of new AI productivity features in 2026 - here's what to expect
entries.snippet: Microsoft has announced a set of new AI-powered productivity features for Windows 11, scheduled for release in early 2026. These features aim to enhance user productivity through advanced AI integration. Key updates include universal text generation, allowing users to create or rewrite text in any text box across all apps, with offline support on Copilot+ PCs via on-board NPUs. The Outlook app will introduce AI-generated inbox summaries to help users prioritize emails efficiently. Microsoft Word will gain automatic alt-text generation for images, improving accessibility. Additionally, a new "fluid dictation" feature will offer real-time voice-to-text transcription with corrected grammar, punctuation, and removal of filler words. While all these AI features will be available on any Windows 11 PC, Copilot+ devices will offer faster performance through local AI processing.

entries.title: Otter.ai's Sam Liang: We can unlock valuable data from meetings and conversations
entries.snippet:
Sam Liang, CEO of Otter.ai, outlines his vision for transforming business productivity through AI-driven meeting transcription and avatar technology. Founded in 2016, Otter.ai has grown from basic voice-to-text services to a comprehensive platform offering live transcription, searchable meeting archives, and AI chat tools. The company's next frontier is customizable AI avatars that can attend and participate in meetings on behalf of users by leveraging vast personal data like documents, emails, and past meeting transcriptions. While still in prototype, these avatars aim to emulate individuals and eventually represent them fully in both internal and customer interactions.

Liang emphasizes Otter‚Äôs proprietary AI and speech recognition technologies, vast meeting data, and platform-agnostic approach, which he believes give it an edge over Big Tech rivals and other start-ups. Otter has 20 million users and operates with a freemium model to penetrate enterprises from the ground up. Security and privacy are key concerns, with encrypted data storage and user-controlled sharing. Despite intensifying competition and concerns over AI ‚Äúhallucinations,‚Äù Liang remains confident in Otter‚Äôs growth, citing improved model accuracy and strong user value, including saving users an average of four hours per week.

items.title: Choosing the Best: Top 10 Speech to Text Applications of 2026 - Murf
items.snippet: Choosing the best speech to text software has never been easier. Check out our top 10 picks for 2026 and elevate your transcription experience.

v:
üõ†Ô∏è Quick Pick by Need

- **Build into software / product:** Google, Azure, Amazon, Deepgram  
- **Highest accuracy with open models:** Whisper / Whisper variants  
- **Live dictation (writing):** SpeakMac, Superwhisper, Otter  
- **Professional transcription (offline or detailed):** MacWhisper, Dragon Professional  
- **Free/basic:** Gboard, Apple/Windows built-in tools

---

## ‚ö†Ô∏è Skeptical Notes

- *Accuracy claims vary widely in real use.* Many vendors quote ‚Äúbest‚Äù results on clean audio; noisy

v.v:
or overlapping speech often drops performance.  
- *Cloud vs local:* Cloud APIs cost per minute, local/offline tools trade cost for compute and setup.  
- *Integration complexity:* Developer APIs require coding; consumer apps are plug-and
